If you need a quick fix for a specific test, you can cast one of the 
arguments in assertEquals(String expected, String actual) to 
type "Object".  This causes the Object version of assert equals to be 
called, rather than the String version, and you will see the entire 
strings in the failure message.  e.g.,

    assertEquals((Object) "I want to see the whole string", "I did 
see the whole string");


I will sometimes do this when I can't figure out immediately why a 
test is failing.  Other times, I like the "..." behavior.  
Interestingly enough, the "..." behaviour is new to JUnit 3.8--I 
believe that Alex Chafee and others submitted it as a request.

Hope this helps.

Jeff Nielsen


--- In junit@yahoogroups.com, "Robert Huffman" <rhuffman@b...> wrote:
> The behavior of ComparisonFailure.getMessage() is to replace
> equivalient parts of the actual and expected strings with "...". In 
my
> opinion, this is truly dreadful behavior. Yet there seems to be no 
way
> to modify this behavior without changing the source code. And this 
is
> because of what is, IMHO and with all due respect to Beck and Gamma,
> bad design: all the Assert.assert* methods are static.
> 
> While a discussion of the design decisions in junit would probably 
be
> enlightening, that's not my goal; here. I would just like 
suggestions
> of how to get the strings, in their entirities, into the output.
> 
> Perhaps the answer is to write my own subclass of TestRunner, but 
then
> I would have to figure out how to integrate the new TestRunner into
> JBuilder.
> 
> Any help would be appreciated.
